item.title: Pakistan Ex-President Musharraf Arrested
item.description: Former Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf was arrested early Friday and presented in court, a day after a judge ordered his detention on a "terrorism" charge.

item.title: French Family in Cameroon Freed
item.description: Seven French nationals, including four children, who were kidnapped by suspected Islamist militants in February in Cameroon, were freed unharmed, said officials from both countries.

item.title: Venezuela Vote Faces Review
item.description: Venezuela's political crisis eased after the country's top election agency said it would carry out an audit of last weekend's contested presidential vote and include the opposition as observers.

item.title: Italy's Left Rallies Around Prodi
item.description: Italy's Democratic Party leaders have decided to nominate Romano Prodi as president, dashing hopes of any cross-party agreement to form a coalition government and making fresh elections likely as early as this summer.

item.title: Hungary Ready to Compromise With EU
item.description: Viktor Orban said he is willing to amend two of three controversial laws, but will surrender a right to impose new taxes.

item.title: More in Euro Zone Are Underemployed
item.description: Growing numbers of workers in the euro zone are unable to work as many hours as they would like, casting new light on the grim outlook for consumers that could depress the region's growth prospects for some time.

item.title: Leaders to Boost Force in Central Africa
item.description: African leaders resolved to boost the size of a regional peacekeeping force in Central African Republic amid intensifying violence after a rebel coup.

item.title: U.S. Probes New Syria Weapons Allegations
item.description: Suspicions that Syrian forces used small amounts of chemical weapons in recent fighting are being reviewed by U.S. intelligence.

item.title: Illegal Migration Into EU Drops
item.description: The number of people trying to illegally enter the European Union dropped by nearly half in 2012, the EU border agency said Thursday, even as tensions over migration remain high across the Continent.

item.title: French Court Summons Lagarde
item.description: IMF chief Lagarde will be questioned as part of a probe into whether she was complicit in alleged misuse of public funds as French finance minister.

item.title: Germany Approves Cyprus Bailout
item.description: Germany's parliament voted in favor of aid for troubled Cyprus with a large majority, giving Chancellor Angela Merkel's euro-crisis policies broad backing ahead of elections in the fall.

item.title: Portugal Moves to Keep Bailout on Track
item.description: The Portuguese government said that it has identified a series of spending cuts to fill a budget hole and keep its bailout on track.

item.title: Venezuela Opposition Stymied by Chávez Loyalists
item.description: Friday's swearing-in of Venezuela's acting President Nicolás Maduro despite a disputed election points to a sobering reality: Most of the country's institutions are stacked with loyalists to his mentor.

item.title: China Probes Flu's Spread Within a Family
item.description: Chinese health authorities said they were investigating the possibility that a new form of bird flu has passed between members of a family in Shanghai.

item.title: Parents of China Victim Get U.S. Visas
item.description: U.S. officials issued visas to the parents of Lu Lingzi, the Chinese student killed on Monday in the Boston Marathon bombing, as people in her hometown said the family was struggling with the loss of its only daughter.

item.title: Home Prices Keep Climbing in China
item.description: Average home prices in key Chinese cities were higher in March, indicating recent government efforts to control the unruly real-estate market are having little effect.

item.title: Thousands March in Argentina to Protest Kirchner's Judicial Plan
item.description: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets in Argentina's capital to protest President Cristina Kirchner's plan to overhaul the judicial system.

item.title: Migrant Workers Shot in Greece
item.description: Parties across the political spectrum condemned a shooting attack on immigrant farmworkers in western Greece, an incident that has shocked the country.

item.title: BOJ Official Sees Inflation
item.description: Japan's inflation rate will likely top 1% in the next fiscal year, a Bank of Japan policy board member said, adding to expectations that the central bank will revise its price forecasts higher.

item.title: North Korea Adds Conditions for Talks
item.description: North Korea dimmed prospects for dialogue with Washington or Seoul further on Thursday, saying that any talks would take place only after the removal of sanctions and the end of military drills in the South.

item.title: Russia Opens New Case Against Activist
item.description: Russian authorities filed another criminal case against opposition leader Alexei Navalny on Thursday, the morning after proceedings in the first of many cases against the vocal critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin kicked off in the city of Kirov.

item.title: Dubai Airport Sees Potential For U.S. Customs Post
item.description: Dubai's airport authority said it would welcome any effort by the U.S. to set up a customs post for airline passengers heading to the country from the Gulf emirate.

item.title: India Announces Package to Boost Exports
item.description: India announced a package worth an estimated $555 million to stimulate its exports, but industry bodies said they had been hoping for bigger measures to help weather the slowdown in demand from Western economies.

item.title: Philippines to Remove Ship From Reef
item.description: Philippine officials plan to remove a Chinese fishing vessel from a protected coral reef where it ran aground as its crew was allegedly smuggling frozen anteaters.

item.title: Director Mira Nair on 'The Reluctant Fundamentalist'
item.description: It took her more than five years to make the film, which will challenge American audiences with its portrait of a young Pakistani man who becomes disenchanted with the U.S.

item.title: Women on the Verge
item.description: After a record Morisot sale in London, art collectors are scrambling to identify undervalued female artists; the $1 million club.

item.title: Pulitzer-Winning Breaking-News Photography
item.description: A set of photos by Rodrigo Abd, Manu Brabo, Narciso Contreras, Khalil Hamra and Muhammed Muheisen, all of the Associated Press, won the Pulitzer Prize for breaking-news photography.

item.title: Lamborghinis and Camels, on Patrol
item.description: Police officers in the emirate of Dubai recently began patrolling in a Lamborghini Aventador. But they aren't the first police officers to hop a cool ride.

item.title: The American Who Tells Russia How Bad Things Are in America
item.description: Clevelander Tim Kirby is making a name for himself inside Russia as a kind of Kremlin-appointed Joe the Plumber who explains a broken America to Russian listeners.

item.title: Photos of the Day: April 18
item.description: In today's pictures, a woman waits for medication in South Sudan, a sinkhole swallows three cars in Chicago, a man carries his mother on a pilgrimage in India, and more.
